captions.text:
How to Live in Your Car. Whether you have
to move into your car or you want to, there

are some bases you need to cover. You will
need Pillows Blankets or a sleeping bag Cooler

Camp stove Voltage converter Access to restrooms
Places to park overnight and hot-water bottle.

Step 1. Furnish your car with blankets (at
least one made of wool, for warmth); a couple

of pillows; a cooler; a camp stove; and a
voltage converter so you can power appliances

with your cigarette lighter. Consider removing
the passenger and rear seats for more room.

Step 2. Know where you can park at night.
Trucker areas off the interstate are usually

safe, as are hospital parking lots. Wal-Mart
allows RV’s and cars to park in their lots

overnight. Never park near a school. Someone
is sure to call the authorities. Step 3. Shopping

malls, supermarkets, and hospitals are good
places to wash up. For a shower, go to a truck

stop and ask around for a shower coupon; truckers
usually have more than they need and are happy

to give some away. A gym membership will allow
you to shower regularly. Step 4. Buy gas off-hours

at stations with convenience stores. When
you go to pay, ask if you can use the microwave

to nuke a meal, like a baked potato or a frozen
entrée. Step 5. Stock up on foods that are

nutritious and don’t require refrigeration,
such as peanut butter, beans, and cereals.

Step 6. Stay warm in winter with the help
of a hot water bottle; stay cool in summer

by parking in the shade and spending the hottest
part of the day -- noon to two -- in someplace

air conditioned, like the library or mall.
Did you know Mad Money host Jim Cramer once
lived in his car for five months.

title: How to Live in Your Car

comments.author: afrodylan671

comments.text:
It's not that people make bad decisions, some people have no control on 
where they could stay if living with someone else. I live in my car now 
because of my mom. She would always like to fight and argue for no reason 
(cocaine is a hell of a drug) while my great grandmother is stressing so 
badly, I just took it upon myself to leave for the sake of my great 
grandmother. Sometimes you have to do what's right even when its not right 
for you. I honestly feel a lot better getting out of the house even though 
I have no where to go. You also don't need most of these things in the 
video. Mostly blankets, food stamps & gas. ((DON'T TRICK OFF)) To get gas I 
usually have something pawned to get cash or ask around, it doesn't hurt to 
ask. I get online every day to fill out applications from my tablet or 
phone, I go to a friend place to shower and that's that. It's not fun or 
easy but for me I'd rather do this than having to put up with my mom, it's 
sad but true. For anyone who is going through the same I wish you the best 
of luck! ﻿

comments.author: mookixox

comments.text:
Reasons this becomes necessary:
1.  BAD CHOICES.  Yes, they happen.  People make them.  Some people find 
themselves split up from their partners with mounting debt, bad credit, not 
enough income to qualify for even a studio apartment and no friends willing 
to take them in (or able).  If you charge your credit cards up thinking 
you'll always have a great job and then BAM one day that job is gone and 
you become three months behind on the rent and get evicted then you'll be 
thankful for the car.  I drive past a homeless village underneath a bridge 
every day and thank God I have a paid for hatchback if that ever becomes 
me.﻿

comments.author: John Robert Parkins

comments.text:
Don't park in front of people's houses where they can look out and see you. 
Look for places to park that do not have much pedestrian access. Like wood 
chip sidewalks, gravel, etc. If you are male, pee in Gatorade type bottles 
and do not leave any trash in the area. It is also good to park around 
other RV's so that if the cops do come and hassle, there are others in the 
area doing the same thing as you. If you get cold at night, turn on your 
car engine and run the heat. Make sure you lock all your doors at night. 
When you park, go to sleep, don't bring attention to yourself. If the cops 
do come and hassle you, have an idea of what you are going to say before 
you get flashlight in your eyes and knock on your window. I was hassled by 
cops and I used the information from the Youtube video "Flex your rights" 
series. If you have the money, invest in some tinted windows. I saw they 
sell them pre cut for your car. GOOD LUCK TO EVERYONE!!﻿

comments.text:
Fucking sad how ignorant you are! ok first off let me tell you something 
maybe your parent forgot to teach you, never judge people specially the 
ones you dont know, look five years ago it was the year 2009, i was 20 
years old and i was living in my car for a year and a half, guess why? i 
was working 2 jobs as a valet attendant from 4pm to 10pm and 11pm to 7:30 
am, i was making 35 hundred every month, even thought i was able to pay 
500$ for a efficiency, i refuse! why? why pay 500 bucks to go to sleep 
only, when i was able to do that in my 2002 nissan sentra (witch i prepare 
for the situation by buying a silent generator that i put in the truck, a 
portable a/c  and a carbon monoxide battery detector) and save the money, 
yeah! do the math i was saving almost 3k every month, my monthly expenses 
where 100$ for my car insurance (PIP), 400$ for gas, 50$ phone, 50$ gym (no 
contract) why gym? to stay occupied doing exercise playing in the pool and 
take a shower before going to sleep and food was free in the hotels, thank 
you Marriott. What did i accomplish from this? in 10 month i bought my 
favorite car back then a 2007 infiniti m35 salvage from the auction 
(copart) for 8000$ plus 1500$ to fix it and 8 month later i had 25K in my 
bank account and my favorite car!!! (i was 22 years old). Why im telling 
you all this? not to judge you but to make you understand we all think 
different and those where my choices and i dont regretted, hope you learn 
not to judge a book by its cover next time.
